timeline.message: Update dynamodb quickstart to use new amazon-services extension, quickstart for amazon-s3 extension
Update dynamodb quickstart to use new amazon-services extension, quickstart for amazon-s3 extension

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            Create a Dynamodb table using AWS CLI using localstack profile.
          
          
            
            Create a DynamoDB table using AWS CLI and the localstack profile.
timeline.author: gsmet
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,106 @@
+# Quarkus demo: DynamoDB Client
+
+This example showcases how to use the AWS DynamoDB client with Quarkus. As a prerequisite install Install [AWS Command line interface](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-install.html).
+
+# DynamoDB local instance
+
+Just run it as follows:
+`docker run --rm -p 8000:4569 -e SERVICES=dynamodb -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+DynamoDB listens on `localhost:8000` for REST endpoints.
+
+Create an AWS profile for your local instance using AWS CLI:
+
+```
+$ aws configure --profile localstack
+AWS Access Key ID [None]: test-key
+AWS Secret Access Key [None]: test-secret
+Default region name [None]: us-east-1
+Default output format [None]:
+```
+
+## Create table
+
+Create a Dynamodb table using AWS CLI using localstack profile.

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            - Run `mvn clean package` and then `java -jar ./target/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner.jar`
          
          
            
            - Run `./mvnw clean package` and then `java -jar ./target/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner.jar`
timeline.author: gsmet
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,106 @@
+# Quarkus demo: DynamoDB Client
+
+This example showcases how to use the AWS DynamoDB client with Quarkus. As a prerequisite install Install [AWS Command line interface](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-install.html).
+
+# DynamoDB local instance
+
+Just run it as follows:
+`docker run --rm -p 8000:4569 -e SERVICES=dynamodb -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+DynamoDB listens on `localhost:8000` for REST endpoints.
+
+Create an AWS profile for your local instance using AWS CLI:
+
+```
+$ aws configure --profile localstack
+AWS Access Key ID [None]: test-key
+AWS Secret Access Key [None]: test-secret
+Default region name [None]: us-east-1
+Default output format [None]:
+```
+
+## Create table
+
+Create a Dynamodb table using AWS CLI using localstack profile.
+```
+aws dynamodb create-table --table-name QuarkusFruits \
+                          --attribute-definitions AttributeName=fruitName,AttributeType=S \
+                          --key-schema AttributeName=fruitName,KeyType=HASH \
+                          --provisioned-throughput ReadCapacityUnits=1,WriteCapacityUnits=1 \
+                          --profile localstack --endpoint-url=http://localhost:8000
+```
+
+# Run the demo on dev mode
+
+- Run `mvn clean package` and then `java -jar ./target/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner.jar`

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            - In dev mode `mvn clean quarkus:dev`
          
          
            
            - In dev mode `./mvnw clean quarkus:dev`
timeline.author: gsmet

@@ -0,0 +1,106 @@
+# Quarkus demo: DynamoDB Client
+
+This example showcases how to use the AWS DynamoDB client with Quarkus. As a prerequisite install Install [AWS Command line interface](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-install.html).
+
+# DynamoDB local instance
+
+Just run it as follows:
+`docker run --rm -p 8000:4569 -e SERVICES=dynamodb -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+DynamoDB listens on `localhost:8000` for REST endpoints.
+
+Create an AWS profile for your local instance using AWS CLI:
+
+```
+$ aws configure --profile localstack
+AWS Access Key ID [None]: test-key
+AWS Secret Access Key [None]: test-secret
+Default region name [None]: us-east-1
+Default output format [None]:
+```
+
+## Create table
+
+Create a Dynamodb table using AWS CLI using localstack profile.
+```
+aws dynamodb create-table --table-name QuarkusFruits \
+                          --attribute-definitions AttributeName=fruitName,AttributeType=S \
+                          --key-schema AttributeName=fruitName,KeyType=HASH \
+                          --provisioned-throughput ReadCapacityUnits=1,WriteCapacityUnits=1 \
+                          --profile localstack --endpoint-url=http://localhost:8000
+```
+
+# Run the demo on dev mode
+
+- Run `mvn clean package` and then `java -jar ./target/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner.jar`
+- In dev mode `mvn clean quarkus:dev`

+# Quarkus demo: DynamoDB Client
+
+This example showcases how to use the AWS DynamoDB client with Quarkus. As a prerequisite install Install [AWS Command line interface](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-install.html).
+
+# DynamoDB local instance
+
+Just run it as follows:
+`docker run --rm -p 8000:4569 -e SERVICES=dynamodb -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`

+DynamoDB listens on `localhost:8000` for REST endpoints.
+
+Create an AWS profile for your local instance using AWS CLI:
+
+```
+$ aws configure --profile localstack
+AWS Access Key ID [None]: test-key
+AWS Secret Access Key [None]: test-secret
+Default region name [None]: us-east-1
+Default output format [None]:
+```
+
+## Create table
+
+Create a Dynamodb table using AWS CLI using localstack profile.
+```
+aws dynamodb create-table --table-name QuarkusFruits \
+                          --attribute-definitions AttributeName=fruitName,AttributeType=S \
+                          --key-schema AttributeName=fruitName,KeyType=HASH \

@@ -0,0 +1,106 @@
+# Quarkus demo: DynamoDB Client
+
+This example showcases how to use the AWS DynamoDB client with Quarkus. As a prerequisite install Install [AWS Command line interface](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-install.html).
+
+# DynamoDB local instance
+
+Just run it as follows:
+`docker run --rm -p 8000:4569 -e SERVICES=dynamodb -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+DynamoDB listens on `localhost:8000` for REST endpoints.
+
+Create an AWS profile for your local instance using AWS CLI:
+
+```
+$ aws configure --profile localstack
+AWS Access Key ID [None]: test-key
+AWS Secret Access Key [None]: test-secret
+Default region name [None]: us-east-1
+Default output format [None]:
+```
+
+## Create table
+
+Create a Dynamodb table using AWS CLI using localstack profile.
+```
+aws dynamodb create-table --table-name QuarkusFruits \
+                          --attribute-definitions AttributeName=fruitName,AttributeType=S \
+                          --key-schema AttributeName=fruitName,KeyType=HASH \
+                          --provisioned-throughput ReadCapacityUnits=1,WriteCapacityUnits=1 \
+                          --profile localstack --endpoint-url=http://localhost:8000
+```
+
+# Run the demo on dev mode
+
+- Run `mvn clean package` and then `java -jar ./target/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner.jar`
+- In dev mode `mvn clean quarkus:dev`
+
+Go to [`http://localhost:8080/fruits.html`](http://localhost:8080/fruits.html), it should show a simple App to manage list of Fruits. 
+You can add fruits to the list via the form.
+
+Alternatively, go to [`http://localhost:8080/async-fruits.html`](http://localhost:8080/async-fruits.html) with the simple App communicating with Async resources.
+
+# Running in native
+
+You can compile the application into a native binary using:

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            `mvn clean install -Pnative`
          
          
            
            `./mvnw clean install -Pnative`

+# Quarkus demo: DynamoDB Client
+
+This example showcases how to use the AWS DynamoDB client with Quarkus. As a prerequisite install Install [AWS Command line interface](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-install.html).
+
+# DynamoDB local instance
+
+Just run it as follows:
+`docker run --rm -p 8000:4569 -e SERVICES=dynamodb -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+DynamoDB listens on `localhost:8000` for REST endpoints.
+
+Create an AWS profile for your local instance using AWS CLI:
+
+```
+$ aws configure --profile localstack
+AWS Access Key ID [None]: test-key
+AWS Secret Access Key [None]: test-secret
+Default region name [None]: us-east-1
+Default output format [None]:
+```
+
+## Create table
+
+Create a Dynamodb table using AWS CLI using localstack profile.
+```
+aws dynamodb create-table --table-name QuarkusFruits \
+                          --attribute-definitions AttributeName=fruitName,AttributeType=S \
+                          --key-schema AttributeName=fruitName,KeyType=HASH \
+                          --provisioned-throughput ReadCapacityUnits=1,WriteCapacityUnits=1 \
+                          --profile localstack --endpoint-url=http://localhost:8000
+```
+
+# Run the demo on dev mode
+
+- Run `mvn clean package` and then `java -jar ./target/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner.jar`
+- In dev mode `mvn clean quarkus:dev`
+
+Go to [`http://localhost:8080/fruits.html`](http://localhost:8080/fruits.html), it should show a simple App to manage list of Fruits. 
+You can add fruits to the list via the form.
+
+Alternatively, go to [`http://localhost:8080/async-fruits.html`](http://localhost:8080/async-fruits.html) with the simple App communicating with Async resources.
+
+# Running in native
+
+You can compile the application into a native binary using:
+
+`mvn clean install -Pnative`

@@ -0,0 +1,106 @@
+# Quarkus demo: DynamoDB Client
+
+This example showcases how to use the AWS DynamoDB client with Quarkus. As a prerequisite install Install [AWS Command line interface](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-install.html).
+
+# DynamoDB local instance
+
+Just run it as follows:
+`docker run --rm -p 8000:4569 -e SERVICES=dynamodb -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+DynamoDB listens on `localhost:8000` for REST endpoints.
+
+Create an AWS profile for your local instance using AWS CLI:
+
+```
+$ aws configure --profile localstack
+AWS Access Key ID [None]: test-key
+AWS Secret Access Key [None]: test-secret
+Default region name [None]: us-east-1
+Default output format [None]:
+```
+
+## Create table
+
+Create a Dynamodb table using AWS CLI using localstack profile.
+```
+aws dynamodb create-table --table-name QuarkusFruits \
+                          --attribute-definitions AttributeName=fruitName,AttributeType=S \
+                          --key-schema AttributeName=fruitName,KeyType=HASH \
+                          --provisioned-throughput ReadCapacityUnits=1,WriteCapacityUnits=1 \
+                          --profile localstack --endpoint-url=http://localhost:8000
+```
+
+# Run the demo on dev mode
+
+- Run `mvn clean package` and then `java -jar ./target/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner.jar`
+- In dev mode `mvn clean quarkus:dev`
+
+Go to [`http://localhost:8080/fruits.html`](http://localhost:8080/fruits.html), it should show a simple App to manage list of Fruits. 
+You can add fruits to the list via the form.
+
+Alternatively, go to [`http://localhost:8080/async-fruits.html`](http://localhost:8080/async-fruits.html) with the simple App communicating with Async resources.
+
+# Running in native
+
+You can compile the application into a native binary using:
+
+`mvn clean install -Pnative`
+
+and run with:
+
+`./target/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner` 
+
+
+# Running native in container
+
+Build a native image in container by running:
+
+`mvn package -Pnative -Dnative-image.docker-build=true`

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            Create a Dynamodb table using AWS CLI using your default AWS profile
          
          
            
            Create a DynamoDB table using AWS CLI and your default AWS profile:
timeline.author: gsmet
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,106 @@
+# Quarkus demo: DynamoDB Client
+
+This example showcases how to use the AWS DynamoDB client with Quarkus. As a prerequisite install Install [AWS Command line interface](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-install.html).
+
+# DynamoDB local instance
+
+Just run it as follows:
+`docker run --rm -p 8000:4569 -e SERVICES=dynamodb -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+DynamoDB listens on `localhost:8000` for REST endpoints.
+
+Create an AWS profile for your local instance using AWS CLI:
+
+```
+$ aws configure --profile localstack
+AWS Access Key ID [None]: test-key
+AWS Secret Access Key [None]: test-secret
+Default region name [None]: us-east-1
+Default output format [None]:
+```
+
+## Create table
+
+Create a Dynamodb table using AWS CLI using localstack profile.
+```
+aws dynamodb create-table --table-name QuarkusFruits \
+                          --attribute-definitions AttributeName=fruitName,AttributeType=S \
+                          --key-schema AttributeName=fruitName,KeyType=HASH \
+                          --provisioned-throughput ReadCapacityUnits=1,WriteCapacityUnits=1 \
+                          --profile localstack --endpoint-url=http://localhost:8000
+```
+
+# Run the demo on dev mode
+
+- Run `mvn clean package` and then `java -jar ./target/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner.jar`
+- In dev mode `mvn clean quarkus:dev`
+
+Go to [`http://localhost:8080/fruits.html`](http://localhost:8080/fruits.html), it should show a simple App to manage list of Fruits. 
+You can add fruits to the list via the form.
+
+Alternatively, go to [`http://localhost:8080/async-fruits.html`](http://localhost:8080/async-fruits.html) with the simple App communicating with Async resources.
+
+# Running in native
+
+You can compile the application into a native binary using:
+
+`mvn clean install -Pnative`
+
+and run with:
+
+`./target/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner` 
+
+
+# Running native in container
+
+Build a native image in container by running:
+
+`mvn package -Pnative -Dnative-image.docker-build=true`
+
+Build a docker image:
+`docker build -f src/main/docker/Dockerfile.native -t quarkus/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart .`
+
+Create a network that connect your container with localstack
+`docker network create localstack`
+
+Start localstack and connect to the network
+`docker run --rm --network=localstack --name localstack -p 8008:4569 -e SERVICES=dynamodb -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+Don't forget to create a Dynamo table (see above). And run quickstart container connected to that network (note that we're using internal port of the localstack)
+`docker run -i --rm --network=localstack -p 8080:8080 quarkus/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart -Dquarkus.dynamodb.endpoint-override=http://localstack:4569`
+
+Go to [`http://localhost:8081/fruits.html`](http://localhost:8081/fruits.html) or [`http://localhost:8081/async-fruits.html`](http://localhost:8081/async-fruits.html)
+
+# Using AWS account
+
+Before you can use the AWS SDKs with DynamoDB, you must get an AWS access key ID and secret access key. 
+For more information, see [Setting Up DynamoDB (Web Service)](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/SettingUp.DynamoWebService.html).
+
+Create a Dynamodb table using AWS CLI using your default AWS profile

@@ -0,0 +1,106 @@
+# Quarkus demo: DynamoDB Client
+
+This example showcases how to use the AWS DynamoDB client with Quarkus. As a prerequisite install Install [AWS Command line interface](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-install.html).
+
+# DynamoDB local instance
+
+Just run it as follows:
+`docker run --rm -p 8000:4569 -e SERVICES=dynamodb -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+DynamoDB listens on `localhost:8000` for REST endpoints.
+
+Create an AWS profile for your local instance using AWS CLI:
+
+```
+$ aws configure --profile localstack
+AWS Access Key ID [None]: test-key
+AWS Secret Access Key [None]: test-secret
+Default region name [None]: us-east-1
+Default output format [None]:
+```
+
+## Create table
+
+Create a Dynamodb table using AWS CLI using localstack profile.
+```
+aws dynamodb create-table --table-name QuarkusFruits \
+                          --attribute-definitions AttributeName=fruitName,AttributeType=S \
+                          --key-schema AttributeName=fruitName,KeyType=HASH \
+                          --provisioned-throughput ReadCapacityUnits=1,WriteCapacityUnits=1 \
+                          --profile localstack --endpoint-url=http://localhost:8000
+```
+
+# Run the demo on dev mode
+
+- Run `mvn clean package` and then `java -jar ./target/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner.jar`
+- In dev mode `mvn clean quarkus:dev`
+
+Go to [`http://localhost:8080/fruits.html`](http://localhost:8080/fruits.html), it should show a simple App to manage list of Fruits. 
+You can add fruits to the list via the form.
+
+Alternatively, go to [`http://localhost:8080/async-fruits.html`](http://localhost:8080/async-fruits.html) with the simple App communicating with Async resources.
+
+# Running in native
+
+You can compile the application into a native binary using:
+
+`mvn clean install -Pnative`
+
+and run with:
+
+`./target/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner` 
+
+
+# Running native in container
+
+Build a native image in container by running:
+
+`mvn package -Pnative -Dnative-image.docker-build=true`
+
+Build a docker image:
+`docker build -f src/main/docker/Dockerfile.native -t quarkus/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart .`
+
+Create a network that connect your container with localstack
+`docker network create localstack`
+
+Start localstack and connect to the network
+`docker run --rm --network=localstack --name localstack -p 8008:4569 -e SERVICES=dynamodb -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+Don't forget to create a Dynamo table (see above). And run quickstart container connected to that network (note that we're using internal port of the localstack)
+`docker run -i --rm --network=localstack -p 8080:8080 quarkus/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart -Dquarkus.dynamodb.endpoint-override=http://localstack:4569`
+
+Go to [`http://localhost:8081/fruits.html`](http://localhost:8081/fruits.html) or [`http://localhost:8081/async-fruits.html`](http://localhost:8081/async-fruits.html)
+
+# Using AWS account
+
+Before you can use the AWS SDKs with DynamoDB, you must get an AWS access key ID and secret access key. 
+For more information, see [Setting Up DynamoDB (Web Service)](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/SettingUp.DynamoWebService.html).
+
+Create a Dynamodb table using AWS CLI using your default AWS profile
+
+```
+aws dynamodb create-table --table-name QuarkusFruits \
+                          --attribute-definitions AttributeName=fruitName,AttributeType=S \
+                          --key-schema AttributeName=fruitName,KeyType=HASH \
+                          --provisioned-throughput ReadCapacityUnits=1,WriteCapacityUnits=1
+```
+
+## Run demo
+
+You can run demo same way as for local instance, but you need to change `application.properties` as follows:

+# Quarkus demo: AWS S3 Client
+
+This example showcases how to use the AWS S3 client with Quarkus. As a prerequisite install Install [AWS Command line interface](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-install.html).
+
+# S3 local instance
+
+Just run it as follows:
+`docker run --rm -p 8008:4572 -e SERVICES=s3 -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+S3 listens on `localhost:8008` for REST endpoints.
+
+Create an AWS profile for your local instance using AWS CLI:
+
+```
+$ aws configure --profile localstack
+AWS Access Key ID [None]: test-key
+AWS Secret Access Key [None]: test-secret
+Default region name [None]: us-east-1
+Default output format [None]:
+```
+
+## Create bucket
+
+Create a S3 bucket using AWS CLI using localstack profile.

+## Create bucket

+`aws s3 mb s3://quarkus.s3.quickstart --profile localstack --endpoint-url=http://localhost:8008`
+

+# Quarkus demo: AWS S3 Client
+
+This example showcases how to use the AWS S3 client with Quarkus. As a prerequisite install Install [AWS Command line interface](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-install.html).
+
+# S3 local instance

+```
+$ aws configure --profile localstack

+AWS Secret Access Key [None]: test-secret
+Default region name [None]: us-east-1
+Default output format [None]:
+```
+
+## Create bucket

+Create a S3 bucket using AWS CLI using localstack profile.
+`aws s3 mb s3://quarkus.s3.quickstart --profile localstack --endpoint-url=http://localhost:8008`
+

+- Run `mvn clean package` and then `java -jar ./target/amazon-s3-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner.jar`

+This example showcases how to use the AWS S3 client with Quarkus. As a prerequisite install Install [AWS Command line interface](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-install.html).

+# Quarkus demo: AWS S3 Client
+
+This example showcases how to use the AWS S3 client with Quarkus. As a prerequisite install Install [AWS Command line interface](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-install.html).
+
+# S3 local instance
+
+Just run it as follows:
+`docker run --rm -p 8008:4572 -e SERVICES=s3 -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+S3 listens on `localhost:8008` for REST endpoints.
+
+Create an AWS profile for your local instance using AWS CLI:
+
+```
+$ aws configure --profile localstack
+AWS Access Key ID [None]: test-key
+AWS Secret Access Key [None]: test-secret
+Default region name [None]: us-east-1
+Default output format [None]:
+```
+
+## Create bucket
+
+Create a S3 bucket using AWS CLI using localstack profile.
+`aws s3 mb s3://quarkus.s3.quickstart --profile localstack --endpoint-url=http://localhost:8008`
+
+# Run the demo on dev mode
+
+- Run `mvn clean package` and then `java -jar ./target/amazon-s3-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner.jar`
+- In dev mode `mvn clean quarkus:dev`
+
+Go to `http://localhost:8080/s3.html`, it should show a simple App to manage files on your Bucket. 
+You can upload files to the bucket via the form.
+
+Alternatively, go to `http://localhost:8080/async-s3.html` with the simple App communicating with Async resources.
+
+# Running in native
+
+You can compile the application into a native binary using:
+
+`mvn clean package -Pnative`
+
+and run with:
+
+`./target/amazon-s3-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner` 
+
+
+# Running native in container (using localstack)
+
+Build a native image in container by running:
+
+`mvn package -Pnative -Dnative-image.docker-build=true`

timeline.author: gsmet
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,99 @@
+# Quarkus demo: AWS S3 Client
+
+This example showcases how to use the AWS S3 client with Quarkus. As a prerequisite install Install [AWS Command line interface](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-install.html).
+
+# S3 local instance
+
+Just run it as follows:
+`docker run --rm -p 8008:4572 -e SERVICES=s3 -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+S3 listens on `localhost:8008` for REST endpoints.
+
+Create an AWS profile for your local instance using AWS CLI:
+
+```
+$ aws configure --profile localstack
+AWS Access Key ID [None]: test-key
+AWS Secret Access Key [None]: test-secret
+Default region name [None]: us-east-1
+Default output format [None]:
+```
+
+## Create bucket
+
+Create a S3 bucket using AWS CLI using localstack profile.
+`aws s3 mb s3://quarkus.s3.quickstart --profile localstack --endpoint-url=http://localhost:8008`
+
+# Run the demo on dev mode
+
+- Run `mvn clean package` and then `java -jar ./target/amazon-s3-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner.jar`
+- In dev mode `mvn clean quarkus:dev`
+
+Go to `http://localhost:8080/s3.html`, it should show a simple App to manage files on your Bucket. 
+You can upload files to the bucket via the form.
+
+Alternatively, go to `http://localhost:8080/async-s3.html` with the simple App communicating with Async resources.
+
+# Running in native
+
+You can compile the application into a native binary using:
+
+`mvn clean package -Pnative`
+
+and run with:
+
+`./target/amazon-s3-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner` 
+
+
+# Running native in container (using localstack)
+
+Build a native image in container by running:
+
+`mvn package -Pnative -Dnative-image.docker-build=true`
+
+Build a docker image:
+`docker build -f src/main/docker/Dockerfile.native -t quarkus/amazon-s3-quickstart .`
+
+Create a network that connect your container with localstack
+`docker network create localstack`
+
+Start localstack and connect to the network
+`docker run --rm --network=localstack --name localstack -p 8008:4572 -e SERVICES=s3 -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+Don't forget to create a S3 bucket (see above). And run quickstart container connected to that network (note that we're using internal port of the S3 localstack)
+`docker run -i --rm --network=localstack -p 8080:8080 quarkus/amazon-s3-quickstart -Dquarkus.s3.endpoint-override=http://localstack:4572`
+
+Go to `http://localhost:8080/s3.html` or `http://localhost:8080/async-s3.html`
+
+# Using AWS account
+
+Before you can use the AWS SDKs with S3, you must get an AWS access key ID and secret access key. 
+For more information, see:
+ - [Sign up for AWS and Create an IAM User](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdk-for-java/v2/developer-guide/signup-create-iam-user.html)
+ - [Set Up AWS Credentials and Region for Development](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdk-for-java/v2/developer-guide/setup-credentials.html)
+
+Create a S3 bucket using AWS CLI using your default AWS profile
+`aws s3 mb s3://quarkus.s3.quickstart.11.22.33`
+
+**NOTE: Please assure the bucket name you created is unique across AWS S3. 
+See [Amazon S3 Bucket Naming Requirements](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/BucketRestrictions.html#bucketnamingrules)**
+
+## Run demo
+
+You can run demo same way as for local instance, but you need to change `application.properties` as follows:

timeline.message: Update dynamodb quickstart to use new amazon-services extension, quickstart for amazon-s3 extension

timeline.bodyText: Use Java 11? I'm getting Quarkus warnings about using Java 8.
timeline.author: oztimpower
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,165 @@
+<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
+<project xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd" 
+    xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0" 
+    xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance">
+    <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>
+
+    <groupId>org.acme</groupId>
+    <artifactId>amazon-s3-quickstart</artifactId>
+    <version>1.0-SNAPSHOT</version>
+
+    <properties>
+        <quarkus-plugin.version>999-SNAPSHOT</quarkus-plugin.version>
+        <quarkus.platform.artifact-id>quarkus-bom</quarkus.platform.artifact-id>
+        <quarkus.platform.group-id>io.quarkus</quarkus.platform.group-id>
+        <quarkus.platform.version>999-SNAPSHOT</quarkus.platform.version>
+        <surefire-plugin.version>2.22.1</surefire-plugin.version>
+        <project.build.sourceEncoding>UTF-8</project.build.sourceEncoding>
+        <maven.compiler.source>1.8</maven.compiler.source>

replies.bodyText: We should still be compatible with Java 8 for now but right it's deprecated.
replies.author: gsmet

replies.bodyText: So i'll keep 1.8 in here as most of the guides uses it too
replies.author: marcinczeczko

timeline.bodyText: Can I suggest literally to copy the mb command instead of saying "Don't forget"?  Easier if you are following the sequence.

+# Quarkus demo: AWS S3 Client
+
+This example showcases how to use the AWS S3 client with Quarkus. As a prerequisite install Install [AWS Command line interface](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-install.html).
+
+# S3 local instance
+
+Just run it as follows:
+`docker run --rm -p 8008:4572 -e SERVICES=s3 -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+S3 listens on `localhost:8008` for REST endpoints.
+
+Create an AWS profile for your local instance using AWS CLI:
+
+```
+$ aws configure --profile localstack
+AWS Access Key ID [None]: test-key
+AWS Secret Access Key [None]: test-secret
+Default region name [None]: us-east-1
+Default output format [None]:
+```
+
+## Create bucket
+
+Create a S3 bucket using AWS CLI and the localstack profile.
+`aws s3 mb s3://quarkus.s3.quickstart --profile localstack --endpoint-url=http://localhost:8008`
+
+# Run the demo in dev mode
+
+- Run `./mvnw clean package` and then `java -jar ./target/amazon-s3-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner.jar`
+- In dev mode `./mvnw clean quarkus:dev`
+
+Go to `http://localhost:8080/s3.html`, it should show a simple App to manage files on your Bucket. 
+You can upload files to the bucket via the form.
+
+Alternatively, go to `http://localhost:8080/async-s3.html` with the simple App communicating with Async resources.
+
+# Running in native
+
+You can compile the application into a native executable using:
+
+`./mvnw clean package -Pnative`
+
+and run with:
+
+`./target/amazon-s3-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner` 
+
+
+# Running native in container (using localstack)
+
+Build a native image in container by running:
+
+`./mvnw package -Pnative -Dnative-image.docker-build=true`
+
+Build a docker image:
+`docker build -f src/main/docker/Dockerfile.native -t quarkus/amazon-s3-quickstart .`
+
+Create a network that connect your container with localstack
+`docker network create localstack`
+
+Start localstack and connect to the network
+`docker run --rm --network=localstack --name localstack -p 8008:4572 -e SERVICES=s3 -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+Don't forget to create a S3 bucket (see above). And run quickstart container connected to that network (note that we're using internal port of the S3 localstack)

timeline.bodyText: Perhaps also add a note to destroy the container created earlier in the guide, since if you are following the guide you will still have it running? When you get the port already in use error, yes you go and destroy the old container, however I think it's good to have a reminder?

timeline.bodyText:
Possible to add a note to comment out the quarkus.s3.endpoint-override property in the config file?
I followed the instructions and then had to fight with it a little to work out why it wasn't working, the command line version sets that to = '' yet it does not override what's in the properties file if you forget to do it.

timeline.bodyText: The region parameter is optional. If you have setup the aws-cli via aws configure it's not required. Worth mentioning as such? You can also set it via environment variables since you mention that as an option.  To be honest I'm not sure why would want this as a Java property when it's more suited to the cli to manage per profile.

+
+Build a docker image:
+`docker build -f src/main/docker/Dockerfile.native -t quarkus/amazon-s3-quickstart .`
+
+Create a network that connect your container with localstack
+`docker network create localstack`
+
+Start localstack and connect to the network
+`docker run --rm --network=localstack --name localstack -p 8008:4572 -e SERVICES=s3 -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+Don't forget to create a S3 bucket (see above). And run quickstart container connected to that network (note that we're using internal port of the S3 localstack)
+`docker run -i --rm --network=localstack -p 8080:8080 quarkus/amazon-s3-quickstart -Dquarkus.s3.endpoint-override=http://localstack:4572`
+
+Go to `http://localhost:8080/s3.html` or `http://localhost:8080/async-s3.html`
+
+# Using AWS account
+
+Before you can use the AWS SDKs with S3, you must get an AWS access key ID and secret access key. 
+For more information, see:
+ - [Sign up for AWS and Create an IAM User](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdk-for-java/v2/developer-guide/signup-create-iam-user.html)
+ - [Set Up AWS Credentials and Region for Development](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdk-for-java/v2/developer-guide/setup-credentials.html)
+
+Create a S3 bucket using AWS CLI using your default AWS profile
+`aws s3 mb s3://quarkus.s3.quickstart.11.22.33`
+
+**NOTE: Please assure the bucket name you created is unique across AWS S3. 
+See [Amazon S3 Bucket Naming Requirements](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/BucketRestrictions.html#bucketnamingrules)**
+
+## Run demo
+
+You can run the demo the same way as for a local instance, but you need to change the `application.properties` as follows:
+```
+quarkus.s3.aws.region=<YOUR_REGION>

@@ -0,0 +1,127 @@
+# Quarkus demo: DynamoDB Client
+
+This example showcases how to use the AWS DynamoDB client with Quarkus. As a prerequisite install Install [AWS Command line interface](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-install.html).
+
+# DynamoDB local instance
+
+Just run it as follows:
+`docker run --rm --name local-dynamo -p 8000:4569 -e SERVICES=dynamodb -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+DynamoDB listens on `localhost:8000` for REST endpoints.
+
+Create an AWS profile for your local instance using AWS CLI:
+
+```
+$ aws configure --profile localstack
+AWS Access Key ID [None]: test-key
+AWS Secret Access Key [None]: test-secret
+Default region name [None]: us-east-1
+Default output format [None]:
+```
+
+## Create table
+
+Create a DynamoDB table using AWS CLI and the localstack profile.
+```
+aws dynamodb create-table --table-name QuarkusFruits \
+                          --attribute-definitions AttributeName=fruitName,AttributeType=S \
+                          --key-schema AttributeName=fruitName,KeyType=HASH \
+                          --provisioned-throughput ReadCapacityUnits=1,WriteCapacityUnits=1 \
+                          --profile localstack --endpoint-url=http://localhost:8000
+```
+
+# Run the demo on dev mode
+
+- Run `./mvnw clean package` and then `java -jar ./target/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner.jar`
+- In dev mode `./mvnw clean quarkus:dev`
+
+Go to [`http://localhost:8080/fruits.html`](http://localhost:8080/fruits.html), it should show a simple App to manage a list of Fruits. 
+You can add fruits to the list via the form.
+
+Alternatively, go to [`http://localhost:8080/async-fruits.html`](http://localhost:8080/async-fruits.html) with the simple App communicating with Async resources.
+
+# Running in native
+
+You can compile the application into a native executable using:
+
+`./mvnw clean install -Pnative`
+
+and run with:
+
+`./target/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner` 
+
+
+# Running native in container
+
+Build a native image in container by running:
+
+`./mvnw package -Pnative -Dnative-image.docker-build=true`
+
+Build a docker image:
+`docker build -f src/main/docker/Dockerfile.native -t quarkus/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart .`
+
+Create a network that connect your container with localstack
+`docker network create localstack`
+
+Stop your localstack container you started at the begining
+`docker stop local-dynamo`
+
+Start localstack and connect to the network
+`docker run --rm --network=localstack --name localstack -p 8008:4569 -e SERVICES=dynamodb -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+Create Dynamo table
+```
+aws dynamodb create-table --table-name QuarkusFruits \
+                          --attribute-definitions AttributeName=fruitName,AttributeType=S \
+                          --key-schema AttributeName=fruitName,KeyType=HASH \
+                          --provisioned-throughput ReadCapacityUnits=1,WriteCapacityUnits=1 \
+                          --profile localstack --endpoint-url=http://localhost:8000

@@ -0,0 +1,127 @@
+# Quarkus demo: DynamoDB Client
+
+This example showcases how to use the AWS DynamoDB client with Quarkus. As a prerequisite install Install [AWS Command line interface](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-install.html).
+
+# DynamoDB local instance
+
+Just run it as follows:
+`docker run --rm --name local-dynamo -p 8000:4569 -e SERVICES=dynamodb -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+DynamoDB listens on `localhost:8000` for REST endpoints.
+
+Create an AWS profile for your local instance using AWS CLI:
+
+```
+$ aws configure --profile localstack
+AWS Access Key ID [None]: test-key
+AWS Secret Access Key [None]: test-secret
+Default region name [None]: us-east-1
+Default output format [None]:
+```
+
+## Create table
+
+Create a DynamoDB table using AWS CLI and the localstack profile.
+```
+aws dynamodb create-table --table-name QuarkusFruits \
+                          --attribute-definitions AttributeName=fruitName,AttributeType=S \
+                          --key-schema AttributeName=fruitName,KeyType=HASH \
+                          --provisioned-throughput ReadCapacityUnits=1,WriteCapacityUnits=1 \
+                          --profile localstack --endpoint-url=http://localhost:8000
+```
+
+# Run the demo on dev mode
+
+- Run `./mvnw clean package` and then `java -jar ./target/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner.jar`
+- In dev mode `./mvnw clean quarkus:dev`
+
+Go to [`http://localhost:8080/fruits.html`](http://localhost:8080/fruits.html), it should show a simple App to manage a list of Fruits. 
+You can add fruits to the list via the form.
+
+Alternatively, go to [`http://localhost:8080/async-fruits.html`](http://localhost:8080/async-fruits.html) with the simple App communicating with Async resources.
+
+# Running in native
+
+You can compile the application into a native executable using:
+
+`./mvnw clean install -Pnative`
+
+and run with:
+
+`./target/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner` 
+
+
+# Running native in container
+
+Build a native image in container by running:
+
+`./mvnw package -Pnative -Dnative-image.docker-build=true`
+
+Build a docker image:
+`docker build -f src/main/docker/Dockerfile.native -t quarkus/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart .`
+
+Create a network that connect your container with localstack
+`docker network create localstack`
+
+Stop your localstack container you started at the begining
+`docker stop local-dynamo`
+
+Start localstack and connect to the network
+`docker run --rm --network=localstack --name localstack -p 8008:4569 -e SERVICES=dynamodb -e START_WEB=0 -d localstack/localstack`
+
+Create Dynamo table
+```
+aws dynamodb create-table --table-name QuarkusFruits \
+                          --attribute-definitions AttributeName=fruitName,AttributeType=S \
+                          --key-schema AttributeName=fruitName,KeyType=HASH \
+                          --provisioned-throughput ReadCapacityUnits=1,WriteCapacityUnits=1 \
+                          --profile localstack --endpoint-url=http://localhost:8000
+```
+
+Run quickstart container connected to that network (note that we're using internal port of the localstack)
+`docker run -i --rm --network=localstack -p 8080:8080 quarkus/amazon-dynamodb-quickstart -Dquarkus.dynamodb.endpoint-override=http://localstack:4569`
+
+Go to [`http://localhost:8081/fruits.html`](http://localhost:8081/fruits.html) or [`http://localhost:8081/async-fruits.html`](http://localhost:8081/async-fruits.html)
+
+# Using AWS account
+
+Before you can use the AWS SDKs with DynamoDB, you must get an AWS access key ID and secret access key. 
+For more information, see [Setting Up DynamoDB (Web Service)](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/SettingUp.DynamoWebService.html).
+
+Create a DynamoDB table using AWS CLI and your default AWS profile:
+
+```
+aws dynamodb create-table --table-name QuarkusFruits \
+                          --attribute-definitions AttributeName=fruitName,AttributeType=S \
+                          --key-schema AttributeName=fruitName,KeyType=HASH \
+                          --provisioned-throughput ReadCapacityUnits=1,WriteCapacityUnits=1
+```
+
+## Run demo
+
+You can run the demo the same way as for a local instance, but you need to change the `application.properties`.
+
+- remove or comment out `quarkus.dynamodb.endpoint-override` - as you are going to communicate with the AWS service now
+- remove or comment out `quarkus.dynamodb.aws.region` - region is going to be retrieve via the default providers chain in the following order:
+    - `aws.region` system property
+    - `region` property from the profile file
+- set `quarkus.dynamodb.aws.credentials.type=default` - to use the `default` credentials provider chain that looks for credentials in this order:
